questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a ﬁrst-rank symptom of schizophrenia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Somatic hallucinations The ﬁrst-rank symptoms are: Three hallucinations: Audible thoughts (thought echo) Voices heard arguing (3rd person) Voices heard commenting on one’s actions (running commentary) Three ‘made’ phenomena : Made affect (someone controlling the mood/ affect) Made volition (someone controlling the action – usually a completed act) Made impulse (someone controlling the desire to act – not the completed act but the drive. If the action has been carried out, then the patient admits to ownership of the act, not the impulse behind it) Three thought phenomena : (experiences themselves are more important than later explanations of how a patient interprets them) Thought withdrawal Thought insertion (external agency inserting thoughts into the patient ) Thought broadcast (also called thought diffusion – as if in a television broadcast, everyone comes to know about the patient’s thinking as and when the patient thinks – refers to loss of privacy of thoughts.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of his bizarre behavior, inappropriate smiling while alone, and spending time alone in his room for 2 months. They report that he has been living with them since he dropped out of college a year ago. At times, the patient does not respond to questions asked of him, and at other times, he simply repeats the questions. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Catatonic type of schizophrenia Schizophrenia, the catatonic subtype, is defined by a predominance of symptoms that involve motor behaviors and nonverbal forms of communication such as facial expression. This category includes famous cases of waxy flexibility , echolalia (repeating another’s words inappropriately), and echopraxia (repeating another’s gestures inappropriately).

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: B. Disorganized schizophrenia , may present with a chief complaint of disorganized thoughts like “I came to restore my tranquillity so that I can get what’s coming to me upside down.” Option: C: Patients with paranoid schizophrenia may be relatively high functioning between episodes of psychosis . They may have relatively little thought disorder and may not have other bizarre manners. Option: D. The diagnosis of residual schizophrenia is reserved for patients who have not had prominent positive symptoms (primarily thought disorder and psychosis) for some time and present with primarily chronic negative symptoms (anergia, anhedonia, and flattened affect).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a catatonic symptom?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Astasia–abasia A gait disturbance seen in conversion disorder is called astasia–abasia . It is a wildly ataxic, staggering gait accompanied by gross, irregular, jerky truncal movements, and thrashing and waving arm movements . Patients with the symptoms rarely experience a fall; even if they do, they do not get seriously injured.

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Posturing is maintaining an uncomfortable posture for a long time. Option: B. Negativism is motiveless resistance to all movements; Option: C. Ambitendency is tested by asking the patient to show his tongue – the patient will keep moving it in and out similar to a ‘jack in the box’.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient you have seen twice is brought to your OPD by family members. On previous occasions, he presented with delusions, hallucinations, and prominent negative symptoms. During the visit, he exhibits motoric, waxy flexibility, and resistance to all instructions. He methodically repeats words and phrases and appears to crudely mimic your movements. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schizophrenia, catatonic type Schizophrenia, the catatonic subtype, is defined by a predominance of symptoms that involve motor behaviors and nonverbal forms of communication such as facial expression. This category includes famous cases of waxy flexibility , echolalia (repeating another’s words inappropriately), and echopraxia (repeating another’s gestures inappropriately).

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A: The diagnosis of schizophrenia makes elective mutism very unlikely. Option B: Drug-induced psychosis is unlikely to result in the classical symptoms of catatonic schizophrenia. Option D: There is no evidence of secondary gain, making a diagnosis of malingering similarly unlikely.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male developed auditory hallucinations and disorganized speech, giggling, and mirror gazing for the past eight months. The patient was started with antipsychotic drugs but showed a poor prognosis. What is the most probable diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hebephrenic schizophrenia The patient is suffering from hebephrenic schizophrenia as it shows an early onset and poor prognosis . It is characterized by sudden inappropriate laughter and mirror gazing.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Paranoid schizophrenia is the most common It mainly has positive symptoms and rarely shows negative symptoms . It is characterized by late onset and a better prognosis . Option: C . Catatonic schizophrenia shows a better prognosis Option: D . Simple schizophrenia presents only with negative symptoms. It usually shows a worse prognosis .

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a common feature of schizophrenic auditory hallucinations?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Often continuously present Phonemes are any auditory hallucinations that occur as human voices . Schizophrenic phonemes are usually multiple voices . The voices may or may not be recognizable. These voices are usually male with a different accent but speaking in one’s mother tongue . Schizophrenic hallucinations are usually episodic – almost never continuous . Continuous, non-stop hallucinations should make one suspect the veracity of the reported experience.

questions.text: Loss of insight is a common feature in schizophrenia. Which of the following neurological symptoms is comparable to the loss of insight?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anosognosia Insight is a multidimensional concept; it is not useful to restrict oneself to the assessment of the ‘presence’ or ‘absence’ of insight. Insight is closely related to the neurological symptom of anosognosia. Eg. A patient who is suffering from hemiplegia refuses to accept that he has lost the function of his limb. (‘A’–absence, ‘noso’–ill health or disease, ‘gnosis’–awareness). In visual object agnosia , the subject can recognize that an object is in their field of vision (i.e., the sensation is intact) , but they are unable to recognize what the object or its function is (impaired perception).

questions.text: A person feels very anxious while leaving home. He feels people in the street are watching him and feels very self-conscious about what he does. He tries to interpret different gestures he could see others making in his presence. Which one of the following suits this description best?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sensitive ideas of reference Ideas of reference are seen in paranoid personality disorder where the individual is unduly self-conscious and feels that people take notice of him or observe things about him that he would rather not be seen. It can also precede the development of full-blown schizophrenia , where it is called sensitive ideas of reference or ‘sensitive Beziehungswahn ’.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman who recently gave birth to a baby presents complaining of falling asleep without warning. She often finds that she has collapsed ungracefully on the floor and these episodes tend to occur when she is trying to juggle several tasks at once and feeling overwhelmed. The term used to describe the phenomenon of the sudden loss of muscle tone associated with stressful situations is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cataplexy A sudden loss of muscle tone, such as jaw drop, head drop, weakness of the knees , or paralysis of all skeletal muscles with collapse .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: B. & C. Catalepsy and catatonia are used to describe bizarre movement and posture behaviors found in catatonic schizophrenia. Option: D. Akathisia is a subjective complaint. The patient becomes restless. It is an extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male was brought by his mother with complaints of reduced food intake, sleep, and interaction with family members for almost 3 months. He is seen talking to the wall at times. There is an associated history of episodes of hitting classmates and shouting irrelevantly in class. During the interview, the boy has no complaints and says that he just talks to his friend. The patient has:-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Psychosis The given clinical scenario points towards schizophrenia which is a disorder of psychosis. questions.text: A 22-year-old boy is brought by his mother because of behavioral changes in him. She says that he just sits in the room all day and doesn’t talk or respond to anyone. His food intake and sleep have considerably reduced for 4 months. On examination, there is malnutrition, posturing, and rigidity. There are cut marks on his left wrist. The patient looks like the following. He has ____ type of schizophrenia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Catatonic The image shown is showing posturing. The classic feature of the catatonic type is a marked disturbance in motor function ; this disturbance may involve stupor, negativism, rigidity, excitement, or posturing . Associated features include stereotypies, mannerisms, and waxy flexibility . Mutism is particularly common. During catatonic excitement. Patients need careful supervision to prevent them from hurting themselves or others.

The paranoid type of schizophrenia is characterized by preoccupation with one or more delusions or frequent auditory classically, the paranoid type of schizophrenia is characterized mainly by the presence of delusions of persecution or grandeur. Option: C. Undifferentiated Type. Frequently, patients who have schizophrenia cannot easily fit into one type or another. Option: D. Residual Type. The residual type of schizophrenia is characterized by continuing evidence of schizophrenic disturbance in the absence of a complete set of active symptoms.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient with a history of fatigue, loss of interest in usual activities, low mood, feelings of guilt, decreased appetite, and disturbed sleep for 3 months was brought to the hospital in stuporous conditions with loss of power in all four limbs. Waxy flexibility of muscle tone in the limbs was detected. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Depressive stupor The hallmark symptoms of catatonia- stuporousness, blunted affect, extreme withdrawal, negativism, and marked psychomotor retardation - can be seen in both catatonic and non catatonic schizophrenia, major depressive disorder (often with psychotic features), and medical and neurological disorders. The patient in question has characteristic features suggesting major depression . Hence, a depressive stupor is an appropriate answer.
